tossups.question: A tone poem by this composer opens with a held B in the strings, followed by a piano flourish and a solo clarinet coming in on an F-sharp and then going down to D-sharp, C-sharp, F-sharp. A long, short, long horn call is followed by rapid trills in the high instruments to begin another piece by this composer. This composer’s concertos include one based on Gregorian chant and an unfinished A-major violin concerto completed by Salvatore Di Vittorio. This composer wrote a five movement suite with baroque influences, that includes movements such as (*) “The Hen” and “The Dove.” A work by this composer depicts dancing Naiads and Tritons during the morning hours. In one of his suites, this composer incorporated recorded birdsong to depict the Janiculum Hill and an ostinato to depict soldiers walking along the Appian Way. For 10 points, name this composer of Ancient Airs and Dances, who wrote suites depicting Festivals, Fountains, and Pines of Rome.

Halliwell, Gutteridge, and Aruoma describe a method for calculating this quantity for hydroxyl radicals called the “deoxyribose method.” A plot which shows the change in this quantity with respect to heat of adsorption is called a volcano plot. Hard sphere theory incorrectly predicts a square root of temperature dependence of this quantity. One quantity in a formula for calculating this quantity is replaced by the (*) intrinsic barrier in Marcus theory. One parameter used to calculate this quantity can be expressed as the product of a frequency factor and a steric factor. The temperature dependence of this quantity is given by the Arrhenius equation, and the dimensions of this quantity depend on the order of the reaction. For 10 points, name this constant of proportionality for the speed of reactions.

In a 2016 event, this character was revealed to have succumbed to M-Pox off panel while his ex-girlfriend used telepathy to make everyone think he was still alive. This character and his brother Alex are immune to each others’ powers. This character married Madeleine Pryor without realizing that she was a clone of his former girlfriend, and fathered the time traveler (*) Cable. Due to either brain damage or psychological trauma, this character is unable to turn off his mutant power. This character had an affair with Emma Frost while he was still married to Jean Grey. The most notable part of this character’s costume is made out of “ruby quartz.” For 10 points, name this leader of the X-Men, whose real name is Scott Summers and who shoots energy beams out of his eyes.
tossups.answer: Cyclops [or Scott Summers or Scott before it is read, but prompt on Summers by itself] <DS>

tossups.question: A sect within this tradition was started by a man who disowned his son Zenran for heresy and developed a concept related to citta-prasada. One important work in this tradition mentions nine levels of birth, and another describes the evils that Maitreya must avoid in the future. The name of an important figure in this religious tradition is translated as (*) “Immeasurable Life,” and that figure is notable for his 18th vow. According to some sutras, that man in this religious tradition had been a king named Dharmakāra. Several simplifications to this tradition were made by Honen, whose teachings were expounded by Shinran, the founder of its Shin sect. For 10 points, identify this Mahayana branch of Buddhism, where chanting the name of Amitabha supposedly guarantees practitioners of this faith a future in a place where they can easily obtain Enlightenment.
tossups.answer: Pure Land Buddhism [or Amidism, accept Shin Buddhism before mention, prompt on Mahayana Buddhism or Buddhism] <HB>

tossups.question: Members of this ethnic group founded a Caracas-based company that controlled trade into the Philippines in the late 18th century. During one riot, people who could not speak this ethnic group’s language were assumed to be members of the “vicuna” gang and killed on sight. This ethnic group’s whaling activities led to the creation of a pidgin described by Jon Olafsson, and 32 shipwrecked members of this ethnic group were murdered in Iceland in the 1615 “Slaying of the (*) Spaniards.” The Guipuzcoan Company of Caracas was founded by members of this ethnic group, and this ethnic group’s city of Bilbao was an important whaling center. For 10 points, name this ethnic group native to Northern Spain that speaks a non-Indo-European language.

In contrast with another philosopher from this country, one philosopher said that post-Cantorian set theory gives answers to who can speak of pure multiplicity. The claims that “mathematics is an ontology” and that “ontology is meta-ontological” come from a book written by an author of this country. Both the idealistic and Marxist materialism are intertwined according to a thinker from this country in his essay “Marx in his Limits.” That thinker from this country expanded on the Marxist concept of “contradiction” and “structure in (*) dominance” and wrote the work Reading Capital. In addition to the author of Being and Event, another thinker from this country delivered a lecture on Poe’s “Purloined Letter,” and developed the concept of the mirror stage. For 10 points identify this home country of the 20th century philosophers Alain Badiou, Louis Althusser, and the author of Écrits, Jacques Lacan.

It’s not by Nabokov or Orwell, but Richard Rorty’s Contingency, Irony and Solidarity compares this novel’s theme of “self-creation” to the work of Nietzsche. The town which inspired this novel’s main setting was named Illiers [eel-yay] but changed its name to acknowledge this novel. One character in this novel dies while viewing Vermeer’s View of Delft and was modeled on Anatole France. The narrator of this novel falls in love with (*) Gilberte after meeting her on a path known for its pink hawthorns. That location, which titles one part of this novel, is juxtaposed with the estate of a family which includes Gilberte’s future husband Saint-Loup and the homosexual Baron de Charlus. The Guermantes and the Swanns feature in, for 10 points, which massive novel which includes the episode of the madeleine and was written by Marcel Proust?
tossups.answer: In Search of Lost Time [or À la recherche du temps perdu, or Remembrance of Things Past; anti-prompt on The Prisoner, Swann’s Way or The Guermantes Way] <DS>

tossups.question: The Venetian merchant Gaspero Balbi served as an advisor to one monarch in this country. That monarch in this country used the ahmu-dan system, in which certain villages paid taxes in military service in the village’s regiment. One prince of this country ordered a royal hostage executed after losing a cockfight, only for that hostage to escape, kill him in an elephant duel, and conquer his country. That prince, Min Chit Swa, was defeated by King (*) Naresuan. This country’s Arakan and Hanthawaddy kingdoms were conquered by its expansionist Toungoo Dynasty, and its cities of Mandalay and Pagan were conquered by the British in an expedition up the Irrawaddy River. For 10 points, name this Southeast Asian country led by Aung San Suu Kyi, where massacres of the Rohingya Muslims are currently taking place.

This is the more westerly of the two countries that the Monkey Puzzle tree is native to. This country’s Pacific territories include Robinson Crusoe Island and Alejandro Selkirk Island, which together make up its territory of Juan Fernandez. The name of one of this country’s national parks comes from a Tehuelche word for “blue;” that park is Torres del Paine [Pie-nay]. This country’s (*) Bio-Bio River marks the border of a region that contains its town of Temuco; that region, Araucania, is the namesake of this country’s national epic. This country’s island of Chiloe [Chee-low-ay] is its largest, and its departments of Tacna and Arica were acquired from Bolivia in the War of the Pacific. For 10 points, name this country that shares Patagonia with Argentina.

In a story from this movement, the narrator remembers his mother buying a new carpet to replace one “covered with blood from dad’s dying.” A novel from this movement follows an orphan who falls in love with an older actress, but abandons her to marry the daughter of a rich factory owner. In a story from this movement, a boy hides stolen money in a drain pipe and spites the governor by deliberately (*) losing an athletic event. This movement, which includes John Braine’s novel Room at the Top, had its title coined to promote a play in which Helena encourages her pregnant friend to leave her candy seller husband, but ends up having an affair with him. For 10 points, name this movement associated with Alan Sillitoe’s “The Loneliness of the Long Distance Runner” and Jimmy Porter’s rants against British society in John Osborne’s Look Back in Anger.
tossups.answer: the Angry Young Men [accept kitchen sink realism] <DS>

tossups.question: In a forward to a 2012 book, this thinker compared it to another book by C. Vann Woodward and referenced a chapter called “The Fire This Time.” This scholar created a history of American pragmatism from Emerson to the present, and co-authored a “Poverty Manifesto” where he and his coauthor argue that now is the time to address poverty in America. This thinker collaborated with Michael Lerner on a book that discussed the antisemitism of people like Louis Farrakhan. In his most famous book, this thinker wrote that both mainstream liberal and conservative approaches to repairing (*) race relations in America have failed. This thinker also wrote the introduction to Michelle Alexander’s book The New Jim Crow. For 10 points, name this African American political leader and author, who wrote the books Democracy Matters and Race Matters.

A woman in this novel says that residents of the capital “live in such noise and confusion that their feelings are broken into little bits,” to which the protagonist responds “everything is broken into little bits.” On their second meeting, the protagonist of this novel presents one finger to a woman and says “this remembered you best of all.” That character knocks a dead moth off his window in a montage-like scene from this novel depicting the onset of autumn in the mountains. This novel’s protagonist meets a girl on a train who takes care of a music (*) teacher’s son with tuberculosis. That character in this novel, Yoko, is later pulled from a burning building by the main female character, who is noted for her skill playing the shamisen. For 10 points, name this novel about Shimamura’s visits to the geisha Komako at a hot spring in the title region, a work by Yasunari Kawabata.

This man names a phenomenon where a charged particle accelerates as it scatters between two clouds of charged particles. This man is the alphabetically first namesake of a numerical experiment which surprisingly failed to show mixing in a system of nonlinear oscillators. This man names a formula which includes terms for resonance escape and the fast fission factor, which is this man’s four-factor formula for nuclear reactors. The transition rate is proportional to the square of the associated matrix element in a (*) golden rule named for this scientist. This scientist names a gas of particles which obey statistics named for this man and Dirac, and those particles obey the Pauli exclusion principle. For 10 points, particles with half-integer spin are named after what Italian scientist?

In one painting by this artist, the phallic sausages and deflated bagpipes in the foreground indicate that the blond central figure is actually a boy dressed as a woman. For many years, this artist was attributed with paintings like The Merry Trio and The Last Drop, which are actually by Judith Leyster. This artist of Merrymakers at Shrovetide painted several group portraits of men dressed in (*) orange, white and blue depicting the militia companies of Haarlem. His individual portraits include one of a crazy woman with an owl on her shoulder, called Malle Babbe, as well as a figure whose eyes are traditionally said to follow viewers around the room. For 10 points, name this Dutch artist of the voluptuous Gipsy Girl, who painted a big upturned moustache on The Laughing Cavalier.

The speaker of a poem by this author asks “where is happiness,” as the speaker “cannot guess what I can use an empty heart-cup for.” The speaker of a poem by this author wishes to “wear the brace stockings of night-black lace.” This poet declared that “a girl gets sick of a rose” in a poem whose narrator wants a “peek at the back, where it’s rough and untended and hungry weed grows.” The speaker of a poem by this poet of “the sonnet-ballad” declares that “you remember the (*) children you got that you did not get” and that “abortions will not let you forget.” This poet of “the mother” and A Street in Bronzeville wrote about seven pool players from the Golden Shovel who “sing sin,” “shoot straight,” and “die soon.” For 10 points, name this African-American poet of “We Real Cool.”

A policy carried out by this president was opposed by Jeremiah Evarts, who circulated essays written under the pseudonym “William Penn” to lobby against it. An attempted assassin of this man tried to kill him at the funeral of Warren Evans. The editor John Binns attacked this politician’s supposed execution of six militiamen in the Coffin Handbill. Other than postmaster general Amos (*) Kendall, this president mostly ignored the advice of his kitchen cabinet. This politician beat his attempted assassin, Richard Lawrence, with his cane. This man fought with Nicholas Biddle over the renewal of the Second Bank of the United States’ charter, and he removed many Indian tribes to the west of the Mississippi. For 10 points, name this seventh president of the United States, who was nicknamed “Old Hickory.”

For some organisms, this protein complex has several rods of stacked cylindrical subunits called the Phycobilisome. Jiri Jablonsky and Dusan Lazar discovered the intermediate S-states found in this protein complex, which is an expansion of the 5-stage cycle of S-states discovered and named for Bessel Kok. This protein complex includes a metalloenzyme that contains a core of a calcium and four manganese atoms. This protein complex donates electrons to (*) plastoquinone, which is then passed to cytochrome b6f and then onto a similarly named complex. Photoexcitation of P680 in this complex oxidizes water, which allows this complex to evolve oxygen. For 10 points, name this first reaction complex in photosynthesis, named for the fact it was discovered second.
tossups.answer: photosystem II [or PS II; or PS 2; or oxygen evolving complex; prompt on photosystem or PS] <JS>

tossups.question: This artist created a portrait of Lillian and Dorothy Gish wearing heavy fur coats. Another work by this artist depicts a middle aged woman looking at her fat son with a look of revulsion. This artist depicted a man standing in front of a curtain with his genitals tucked between his legs in “A naked man being a woman, NYC, 1968.” A young man holds an American flag and wears a (*) button reading “BOMB HANOI” in one work by this photographer, who frequently worked in Central Park. Cathleen and Colleen Wade wear opposite expressions but identical clothing in this photographer’s “Identical Twins, Roselle, New Jersey, 1967.” For 10 points, name this American photographer known for her images of dwarves, giants and circus freaks.

Spontaneous potential logging is a technique in this activity which measures small electrical fluctuations with respect to a surface electrode. Thermalization of neutrons from a fast source by hydrogen in pore spaces is one type of wireline measurement, a set of techniques used in this activity. Bright, flat, and dim spots are three types of DHI observed in one technique in this activity. Special vehicles called (*) “thumpers” are used to produce vibrations for seismic surveys as part of this task; those surveys measure the reflected acoustic waves to determine density of rock layers. More direct methods for this activity involve drilling test boreholes. For 10 points, name the activity of searching for deposits of natural resources.
tossups.answer: prospecting [or resource exploration, or other reasonable equivalents; accept more specific types like petroleum prospecting]

tossups.question: One producer of this crop built an opera house in Iquitos with proceeds from it. Henry Wickham introduced this crop to British colonies in Southeast Asia, thus ending another country’s monopoly on it. This crop produced by Carlos Fitzcarrald partially titles the most famous work of Edmund Dene Morel, and a room with furnishings entirely made from a heat-treated product of this crop was built at the Paris World’s Fair. A plantation named for (*) Henry Ford, Fordlandia, was meant to produce this crop, and agents of the Belgian Congo amputated the limbs of those who didn’t meet quotas for production of this crop. This crop can be processed using the “vulcanization” method invented by Charles Goodyear. For 10 points, name this crop whose derivatives are used in automobile tires and pencil erasers.

A 2015 study by the HESS Collaboration studied the sources of TeV [T-E-V] gamma ray emitters from this location, which include the pulsar wind nebula N 157B and the supernova remnant N 132D. Scientists of the Hubble Space Telescope Key Project believe that the knowing the distance modulus to this location is paramount in an accurate estimation of the Hubble constant. A star in at this location is the namesake of an alternate name for luminous blue variables; that star at this location is (*) S. Doradus. The incredibly intense starburst region known as the Tarantula Nebula is found at this location, which is also the site of the 1987A supernova remnant. For 10 points, name this satellite of the Milky Way, the larger of two objects named after a Portuguese Explorer.
tossups.answer: Large Magellanic Cloud [or LMC; prompt on partial answer] Bonuses:

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about the morally questionable theories of Social Darwinism.
parts: This German scientist was an early proponent of social Darwinism but is likely better known for organizing plant and animal species in his Art Forms of Nature. He rejected the monogenesis of the “human races” and supported the theories of Schleicher, who said different races had different evolutionary ancestors.

This four word-phrase, developed in Herbert Spencer’s Principles of Biology, ostensibly tries to summarize the concept of natural selection. It was integrated into On the Origin of Species starting with the 5th edition.

This other British social Darwinist was the first editor of The Economist. He was a member of the so-called Struggle School, which advanced the imperialist idea that nations achieve success by primarily defeating other nations in war.

bonuses.leadin: Constantin Brâncoveanu was a prince of this nation who was sanctified for his and his son’s martyrdom. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this European nation, whose church is home to the second most members among Orthodox churches.
The most important episcopal see in Eastern Orthodoxy is in this city, whose Ecumenical Patriarch is Bartholomew the First. This city is currently known as Istanbul.

This prominent term in Eastern Orthodox, and more generally Christian theology, comes from the Greek word to empty out. In Orthodox Christianity, it refers to form of self-renunciation allowing you to become receptive to the Holy Spirit.

bonuses.leadin: This class of organisms radiated after the Cretaceous-Triassic extinction. For 10 points each:
answers: middle ear bones [or all three of (in any order) hammer, anvil, stirrup or incus, malleus, stapes]
parts: Name this class of organisms that include monotremes, marsupials, and placentals. They are named for certain glands that can produce milk.

Description acceptable. A significant evolutionary event for mammals is when parts of their jaw were repurposed as these items that aid in hearing. The evolution of these things is supported as they arise from the same pharyngeal arch as the mandible and maxilla.

To allow for a longer gestation time and thus a larger baby, placental mammals have lost these bony structures near the pelvis to make childbirth an easier time. These structures help support the marsupial pouch.

bonuses.leadin: One character created by this author is given a dagger to avenge his kidnapped daughter Emilia, but ends up stabbing her instead. For 10 points,
answers: Sturm und Drang [accept Storm and Stress or similar translations]
parts: Name this German playwright and literary critic who wrote Emilia Galotti and Nathan the Wise. His essay Laocoon argues against using similar aesthetic standards for paintings and literature.

Lessing’s theories greatly influenced the development of this movement in German arts, which takes its title from a play by Friedrich von Klinger. Protagonists from this movement tended to be driven by irrational and often criminal passions.

This author wrote about a real-life mercenary with an iron prosthetic hand in his Sturm und Drang play Götz von Berlichingen. A line from that play by this author seems to have inspired Mozart’s canon “Lick me in the arse”.

bonuses.leadin: Hay now: answer the following related to horses in Norse mythology for 10 points each.
parts: This is the horse owned by the builder of the walls of Asgard. Loki transforms into a mare to prevent the builder of receiving his award for building the walls, but not before he has sex with this horse.
With Svaðilfari, Loki gave birth to this eight-legged horse. This horse was ridden by Odin, and some sources say it could travel between worlds easily.
The flying horse Hófvarpnir was ridden by this errand-running goddess. This Aesir goddess was a messenger for Frigga, and went to Hel to negotiate for Baldr’s release after his death.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points, answer some questions about sci-fi films by Stephen Spielberg.
parts: The title character of this Spielberg film is a cute alien who revives dead chrysanthemums, learns English by watching Sesame Street, and tries to phone home.
In Spielberg’s Minority Report, Tom Cruise plays a member of this law enforcement agency, which uses visions of the future to catch people before they violate the law.

This actor played power company worker Roy Neary, who makes an contact with aliens in Close Encounters of the Third Kind. He also starred in Spielberg’s afterlife movie Always and appeared as shark expert Matt Hooper in Jaws.

bonuses.leadin: You are a smallpox virus being transmitted in colonial America. Answer the following about your journey. For 10 points each:
answers: Lord Jeffrey Amherst, first Baron Amherst
parts: You are immensely grateful to this British lord, who initiated a scheme of transmitting you to local Native American tribes via infected blankets while in charge of suppressing Pontiac’s Rebellion

You’re not happy at all that this smallpox-scarred noblewoman recently popularized smallpox inoculation in Britain and its colonies after learning that the Ottomans inoculated their children. Ah, well. Such is life.

After spreading all over North America during the Revolution, you’re upset to find that you’ve been upstaged by a 1792 yellow fever epidemic in this city, which served along with New York as the capital of the United States during its early years.

bonuses.leadin: You’ll get over it, it’s just a phase diagram. Answer some questions about two component systems. For 10 points each:
parts: An important point on a phase diagram is this point, where the binary system melts as a whole instead of forming distinct phases. This point is where the liquidus and solidus meet.
To determine the mole fraction of each part of the binary system in each phase, one should use this equation, named in analogy to the balance achieved by the weights on a simple machine.
In the steel phase diagram, at high temperatures and low carbon concentrations, steel forms this phase. This phase is also known as gamma-phase iron.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, name answer some questions about fictional languages in literature.
parts: In one novel, this author created a language called Gliglico, which the protagonist uses to correspond with his lover La Maga. This author of Hopscotch also inspired a Michelangelo Antonioni film with his story “Blow-Up.”
Anthony Burgess created this slang form of English, heavily permeated by Russian words. In this language, the “orange” in A Clockwork Orange actually means “man.”

This language, whose “ghastly, infra-bass timbre [speaks] to dim seats of consciousness and terror far subtler than the ear” was brought to earth by star-spawn during the Paleozoic. It is named for the underwater city where “dread Cthulhu waits dreaming.”

bonuses.leadin: Polish monarch nicknames weren’t all “the Great” or “the Brave.” For 10 points each:
answers: Augustus III the Strong [accept Augustus the Potent, prompt on Augustus]
parts: Boleslaw the Brave and Boleslaw the Bold were followed by this Boleslaw, known in Polish as Krzywousty. He conquered Pomerania and exiled his brother Zbigniew.

An alternative translation of this king’s nickname may suggest he was named for his huge number of bastards. As Elector of Saxony, he sponsored the porcelain-making experiments of Johann Friedrich Boettger.
A claimant, but never a holder, of the Polish throne was John the Blind, who ruled this kingdom in the modern Czech Republic. Its capital, Prague, was the site of several famous defenestrations.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about bad fates that befell some composers’ premieres. For 10 points each,
parts: This composer’s “Miracle” Symphony was probably not actually given its nickname because a chandelier fell down during the premiere and luckily hurt no one. That event more likely happened during a performance of his 102th symphony, preceding his Drumroll and London ones.
This conductor’s poor premiere of Rachmaninoff's first symphony completely destroyed Rachmaninoff's early career. This Russian’s own works includes the ballets Raymonda and The Seasons.
Conductor Johann von Herbeck died before premiering this symphony, so its composer had to do it himself. Dedicated to Wagner, it is the most revised of its composer’s symphonies.

bonuses.leadin: In the 2017 Chess World Cup, this Norwegian player suffered a surprising defeat at the hands of Chinese GM Bu Xiangzhi. For 10 points each,
parts: Name this current Chess World Champion who earned his title after defeating Vishy Anand in 2013.

Carlsen has often played the Ruy Lopez opening with both the black and white pieces. In the Ruy Lopez, white’s light-squared version of this piece, that only moves diagonally, goes to B5 and attacks a knight.
Carlsen doesn’t play this defensive opening too much when playing as black. This opening that starts with 1.e4e6 [“One E 4, E 6”] has Exchange, Tarrasch and Winawer variations.

bonuses.leadin: A variant of these objects which does not possess an identity element is sometimes spelt without the “i” to indicate this. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these algebraic structures that are closed under their addition and multiplication operations, but might not necessarily have inverses under multiplication.

The central theorem of algebraic geometry, the Nullstellensatz, relates affine varieties to the ideals of rings of these objects. If all of these over some field have solutions in that field, then that field is algebraically closed.

The Nullstellensatz was first proven by this mathematician. This mathematician also names a formal logic system with only a single inference rule, in contrast to the sequent calculus and natural deduction systems.

bonuses.leadin: This story ends by contrasting a character who constantly repeats the phrase “I feel fine” with her lover, who gets another Anis del Toro and comments on the people waiting for a train. For 10 points each:
answers: Ernest Hemingway [or “Papa” Hemingway; or Ernest Miller Hemingway] <JO>
parts: Name this short story, where the American attempts to convince Jig to end her pregnancy, despite never mentioning the word abortion.
The characters in “Hills Like White Elephants” are waiting for a train to this city, where the story’s author stayed in the Hotel Florida as a war correspondent.
Philip Young proposed that this author’s protagonists are “code heroes.” This American wrote “Hills Like White Elephants,” as well as many stories about recurring character Nick Adams.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the havoc a virtual particle popping into existence for less than the Planck time can wreak. For 10 points each:
answers: off mass shell [do NOT accept “on shell”]
parts: It’s less likely that a virtual particle appears between two metal plates than outside of them, due to the limited number of states between them; due to this, the particles cause this attractive force between the two plates, named for a Dutch physicist.

Physicists often use this term to describe virtual particles. This term refers to virtual particles not respecting the relativistic energy-momentum relationship, and so they don’t lie on the ellipse defined by that equation.

A virtual particles might be promoted to a real particle if it appears near a black hole event horizon and contributes to this radiation, which causes a black hole to lose mass. This radiation is named for a British physicist and popularizer of science.

bonuses.leadin: The losers of this battle are locally believed to have been reincarnated as crabs. For 10 points each,
parts: Name this battle described in the Tale of the Heike, which was decided when a morning riptide turned against the eventual losers.
This clan solidified their rule of Japan by defeating their rivals, the Taira, at Dan-no Ura. One of its members, Yoritomo, founded a government based in Kamakura.
The Kamakura government was an example of one of these periods in Japanese history, whose other examples include Ashikaga and Tokugawa.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about different philosophical views on logic. For 10 points each:
answers: classes [accept proper classes; or small classes]
parts: This German logician developed a formal notation for reasoning in his Begriffsschrift. Sentences in his logical system denote truth values, such that the statement 2 squared = 6 would denote false.

As part of his study of logic, Alfred Tarski developed a theory of the “language of the general theory” of these logical objects. In NGB set theory, the proper version of these objects can be treated explicitly, unlike in ZF set theory.

This thinker’s two “Incompleteness Theorems” are central to formal logic as studied today. His first theorem roughly states that for any consistent formal system F, from which some arithmetic can be carried out, there are statements in the language of F which cannot be proven or disproven.

bonuses.leadin: A doll peeks over the side of one of these objects in the painting The Bride Frightened at Seeing Life Opened. For 10 points each,
parts: Identify these objects. In another painting by the same artist, the words “Viva la Vida” are poked into one of these objects above the artist’s name and the year 1954.
Viva la Vida was the final painting of this artist. Her husband, Diego Rivera, also painted a still life of watermelons as his final artwork.
Watermelon symbolism in Mexican painting may be informed by the folk art tradition of this festival, which frequently depicts slices of melon being eaten.

bonuses.leadin: This crisis is named for a former Portuguese diplomat who had his home burned and his possessions stolen during an anti-Semitic riot. For 10 points each,
answers: Henry Temple, 3rd Viscount Palmerston [or Lord Palmerston] <JM>
parts: Name this diplomatic “affair,” during which its namesake man’s birth in Gibraltar meant he had extraterritorial rights as a British citizen.
The Don Pacifico Affair took place in this country. Britain had earlier intervened in this country to secure its independence from the Ottoman Empire under pressure from Philhellenes.

This British Prime Minister gave the Civis Romanus Sum speech in response to the Don Pacifico Affair. That speech created a doctrine by which British citizens anywhere in the world were held to be under the British government’s protection. He was nicknamed “the Mongoose.”

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions about the medieval Welsh poem “Cad Goddeu.” For 10 points each:
parts: “Cad Goddeu” appears in a manuscript attributed to this author, which also contains fragmentary stories of his life. This author was mythologized as a bard at the court of King Arthur, and was once reborn after turning into a corn kernel that got swallowed by the enchantress Ceridwen.

In “Cad Goddeu,” the magician Gwydion summons these things to fight for him. Robert Graves suggested that the poem encoded Celtic religious secrets using the letters of the Ogham alphabet, which were associated with 25 types of these things.

“Cad Goddeu” achieved its widest exposure when it was translated into this language for the lyrics of John Williams’ “Duel of the Fates,” which plays during the final duel with Darth Maul. The Mahabharata was written in this language.
